semantic_identifier: 9748565 - Wavelink Marine Systems - sales_call - Discussion with Joaquin Bennett

hierarchy.meeting_title: 9748565 - Wavelink Marine Systems - sales_call - Discussion with Joaquin Bennett

sections.text: Mina Park: Hi Joaquin—good to see you again. Last time you mentioned you’re getting decent inbound interest, but the sales team is spending a lot of cycles on deals that end up stalling. I’d love to use today to show how Customer_Analyzer can sharpen your messaging for the segments that actually convert, and get you to something you can roll out to the team quickly. Does that still line up with what you’re trying to solve at Wavelink Marine Systems?

Joaquin Bennett: Yeah, that’s right. We have a handful of wins we feel good about, but the reps aren’t consistent in how they pitch, and objections vary a lot. If you can help us standardize what works, I’m interested.

Mina Park: Perfect. I’m going to focus on one piece today: our positioning_recommendation feature, specifically for sales enablement—building an objection-handling guide tied to your strongest value drivers for best-fit accounts. The idea is: we ingest the signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding survey notes, maybe a few product usage events if you have them—and we generate segment-specific messaging blocks your team can actually use.
Joaquin Bennett: When you say “signals,” our CRM data is… not perfect. Fields are missing, and tagging is inconsistent. That’s one reason we haven’t done a ton of segmentation work.

Mina Park: That’s a really common starting point, and it’s actually one of the reasons teams like yours use us. Two things. First, we’re not asking you to boil the ocean on day one—we can start with a small set of reliable fields and a subset of accounts you feel confident about. Second, the recommendations are linked back to the evidence we used, so if the system is leaning too hard on a shaky field, you’ll see it and can adjust. If we start with, say, your last 30 closed-won and 30 closed-lost, plus any notes you have on why they won or lost, we can generate a first pass that’s directionally useful even before you clean everything up.
Joaquin Bennett: Okay. I like the “directionally useful” part, but I don’t want to ship messaging to the team that’s based on bad assumptions. What does the output actually look like?

Mina Park: Totally fair. The output is a set of editable messaging blocks per prioritized segment. So for a segment—let’s say “fleet operators with compliance requirements” versus “smaller marinas modernizing systems”—Customer_Analyzer generates: a value proposition, the top use cases we see in the data and language, differentiators, proof points to collect, pricing/value framing notes, and then an objection-handling playbook. And it’s not a generic template—it uses the observed customer language from your sources. If your customers keep saying “uptime” or “audit readiness” or “reduce manual reporting,” those phrases show up in the recommended positioning.
Joaquin Bennett: The objection-handling playbook is the part I care about most. We see a lot of “this seems expensive,” and “we already have something in place,” and then the reps kind of freestyle.

Mina Park: Exactly. What we’d do is tie those objections to the strongest fit drivers for the segment. So for “already have something,” the playbook might recommend a differentiator like “integrates with existing fleet maintenance tools without replacing them,” and then a proof point to collect—maybe a short case snippet from an account that migrated in phases. For “too expensive,” it’ll guide the rep to value framing: what cost buckets you reduce—downtime, compliance penalties, manual labor—and what metrics to ask for on discovery to quantify it.
Joaquin Bennett: That would help. But we don’t have a lot of clean proof points. We’ve got a couple of anecdotes, not a library.

Mina Park: That’s normal, and we don’t pretend you have everything today. The system actually outputs “proof points to collect” as a checklist, so you can turn it into a lightweight enablement project. For example: “collect time-to-onboard,” “collect reduction in support tickets,” “collect compliance reporting time saved.” Then as you get those, you can drop them back into the messaging blocks. The key is you’re not starting from scratch, and you’re not relying on one rep’s favorite story.
Joaquin Bennett: Makes sense. How fast can we get something usable? We have a Q1 push coming up and I don’t want a two-month implementation.

Mina Park: If we keep the scope tight, we can move quickly. A typical path for a second call like this is: in week one, we connect CRM and import a small set of fields, plus upload any win/loss notes or call summaries you’re comfortable sharing. In week two, we generate the first set of positioning recommendations and objection handling for one or two priority segments. Then you run it with two reps for a week, gather feedback, and iterate. You can have a usable playbook draft in about 10 business days.
Joaquin Bennett: And the data quality issue—are we going to hit a wall if our CRM is messy?

Mina Park: You won’t hit a wall, but you’ll see accuracy improve as data improves. What I’d propose is we define “minimum viable inputs” for the pilot: deal stage history, industry/segment tags if you have them, deal size, and at least some notes on reasons won/lost. If tagging is inconsistent, we can create an interim mapping—basically normalize the tags you do have. The system will also flag missingness—so if “fleet size” is empty on 70% of records, we won’t overweight it.
Joaquin Bennett: That’s reassuring. Another concern: our sales team hates new tools. If this becomes another dashboard they never open, it won’t stick.

Mina Park: Totally. That’s why I’m focusing on outputs your team already uses: a one-page objection-handling guide and messaging blocks you can paste into your existing sales deck and email sequences. Customer_Analyzer can be the “source of truth,” but the reps don’t have to live inside it. You can export the playbook, or we can help you format it into your enablement wiki. The adoption lever is: reps feel like it helps them win faster, not like it’s a reporting requirement.
Joaquin Bennett: Okay. If we did this, what are you asking us to commit to right now?

Mina Park: For today, I’d like to align on a pilot that gets you to a buying decision. Specifically: pick two segments you care about, generate positioning recommendations and an objection-handling guide for each, and run it with a couple reps. If, after that, you see improvement in consistency and shorter time-to-confidence on calls, we move to a broader rollout. To kick that off, I’d need: (1) access to your CRM or an export, (2) 30 minutes with you or someone on your team to confirm which segments matter most, and (3) any existing call notes, survey responses, or win/loss summaries you can share—even if they’re imperfect.
Joaquin Bennett: Two segments is doable. I’d pick “large fleet operators” and “port authorities.” Those have different objections and buying committees.

Mina Park: Great picks—those will show clear differences in drivers and messaging. For large fleet operators, we’ll likely see operational efficiency and uptime language; for port authorities, we may see compliance, procurement, and auditability. The objection-handling will reflect that—so reps aren’t using the same “ROI” story everywhere.
Joaquin Bennett: Pricing—how is the pilot structured? I don’t want a big annual commitment without proof.

Mina Park: We can structure it as a paid pilot that rolls into annual if you choose, or as an annual with a clear success checkpoint at 30 days. Given your Q1 timing, I’d recommend the paid pilot: 30 days, scoped to those two segments and the enablement outputs. At the end, we review the deliverables and what your reps observed—did objections get handled more consistently, did deals progress faster, and did messaging resonate more in early-stage calls.
Joaquin Bennett: I’m leaning toward that. If you can keep it lightweight and not require a data cleanup project first, I’m willing to try.

Mina Park: That’s exactly the plan—lightweight inputs, fast outputs, and a clear path to improve accuracy over time. Next step: I’ll send a one-page pilot plan today—scope, required data fields, timeline, and success criteria. Can we tentatively schedule a 45-minute working session early next week to confirm segments, map your CRM fields, and identify the win/loss notes you want included?
Joaquin Bennett: Yes—Tuesday morning works. Send me the plan and I’ll loop in our sales ops person just for the data export, but I’ll stay the main point of contact.

Mina Park: Perfect. I’ll send the pilot plan and a short checklist of the minimum data we need. And on Tuesday, we’ll aim to leave with: segments locked, data export in motion, and a date for the first positioning and objection-handling draft review. Sound good?
Joaquin Bennett: Sounds good. If you can get us something reps will actually use before the Q1 push, we’re in a great spot.
Mina Park: That’s the goal. I’ll get that over to you today—talk Tuesday, Joaquin.
